Notes: All arriving passengers go through thermal control, as body temperature of each one is measured. At temperature above 37 degrees, the passenger is taken to an isolated room, where a questionnaire is filled and health condition is checked. People with high body temperature also pass through a separate exit. From there, they a medical team takes them to specialized hospitals. https://web.archive.org/web/20200503233128/https://bnr.bg/en/post/101223148/bulgaria-has-taken-all-measures-for-stopping-coronavirus-entering-country

On 30 March 2020 the government adopted a decree for the provision of support of the local business in relation to the COVID-19 crisis. Under this program the government will cover up to 60% from the insurance income of the employees based on the request of the employer and 60% of the part of the social security contributions due by the employer. The remaining 40% of the employees’ remunerations shall be paid by the employer. The measures will apply in respect of employees whose work has been suspended. In case of part-time work the measures will be applied proportionally in respect of the part of the non-working hours.  The support will be available for sectors directly affected by the crisis including retail, restaurants, tourism and those exhaustively listed in the decree of the Council of Ministers. The measures require the employer to pay the full remuneration to the employees, not to terminate any employees due to reduced workload, headcount reductions and closure of part of the enterprise.    [https://web.archive.org/web/20200430230227/https://www.ey.com/gl/en/services/tax/law/ey-global-law-covid19-short-term-work-state-bulgaria; https://web.archive.org/web/20200430225521/https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/03/30/covid-19-bulgaria-cabinet-lists-sectors-eligible-for-aid-prepares-budget-revision/]     The decree can be accessed at: https://web.archive.org/web/20200430231121/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/212

On April 10 2020, the Bulgarian National Bank approved the draft Order to defer and settle required liabilities to banks and their subsidiaries. The approved private moratorium provides an opportunity for changes in the repayment schedule of principal and / or interest rates, without changing key parameters of the credit agreement, such as the interest rates already agreed. The instalments may be deferred for up to 6 months, ending on 31 December 2020. The instalments must have been regularly serviced or with a default of no more than 90 days by 1 March 2020.  Customers must explicitly state to their servicing bank that they wish to benefit from the facilities offered.  Three standardized mechanisms are envisaged: (1) Deferral of principal and interest for up to 6 months; (2)  deferral of principal for up to 6 months; (3) applicable to revolving products.  The respective mechanism will be chosen by mutual agreement between the banks and their clients.  [https://web.archive.org/web/20200428130634/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ikonomicheski]  The full text of the approved order for deferral and settlement of required liabilities to banks and their subsidiaries - financial institutions can be accessed at https://web.archive.org/web/20200428133806/https://www.bnb.bg/bnbweb/groups/public/documents/bnb_pressrelease/pr_20200410_a1_bg.pdf

Bulgaria introduces mandatory wearing of masks in public from April 12 until April 26. This order was later extended till May 13. All citizens in Bulgaria are obliged to wear a disposable or reusable face mask or another option covering the nose and mouth (including cloth, scarf, etc.) when they are in indoor or outdoor public places (including public transport, shops, parks, churches, monasteries, temples, halls, streets, bus stops, etc.). Public places are also considered to be all places which are freely accessible and/or intended for public use. This also applies to places where public services are provided.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201017113504/https://bnr.bg/en/post/101257255/bulgaria-introduces-mandatory-wearing-of-masks-in-public-from-april-12-until-april-26-inclusive    https://web.archive.org/web/20201017114109/https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/04/24/bulgarias-health-minister-extends-order-on-wearing-masks-in-public-places/

Following the Comply or explain principle, on 3 April 2020 the Governing Council of the Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) announced its decision to comply with the EBA Guidelines and required all Bulgarian commercial banks to prepare and submit a unified draft rules for a private Moratoria on bank loan payments in relation to the COVID-19 situation (the “Moratoria”), which would enable banks to offer flexibility and incentives for bank loan payments  Deferral of payments under bank loans for a period of up to six months, but no later than 31 December 2020. Subject to deferring may be all amounts due, or the principal only  The scope of the Moratoria covers the widest possible range of borrowers, both individuals and legal entities. The Moratoria will apply to all bank loans concluded before 31 March 2020, regardless of their type, size, purpose, and established collaterals

If you have flu-like symptoms ( fever, fever, cough, difficulty breathing, loss of smell, disturbance or loss of taste, etc. ) - you should call your GP. He will assess your health, adjust it to the data on previous illnesses in your patient record and give you additional instructions. Be sure to tell your doctor if you have been in contact with a COVID-19 positive person.  If you do not have a general practitioner - contact the regional health inspectorate in whose territory you are located. The phone clerk will explain how to proceed. Inform the employee if you have been abroad for the last 14 days or have established contact with a COVID-19 positive person.    If you assess your health condition or that of your relative as urgent *, call 112, and you must inform the employee if you have been abroad for the last 14 days or have established contact with a person positive for COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200623020401/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/litse-simptomi

As of 17th July 2020, authorities in Bulgaria have decided to lift the compulsory two-weeks quarantine for arrivals from Persons arriving in Bulgaria from European Union Member States, (except Sweden and Portugal), the United Kingdom and the Schengen Zone countries. In addition, they will not be required to present a negative PCR tested for the Coronavirus.  The latest exemptions will also be valid for arrivals from Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay and Ukraine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200820092847/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/bulgaria-lifts-compulsory-14-day-quarantine-for-arrivals-from-uk/

New socio-economic measures worth BGN 1.162.9 billion were presented by the Prime Minister, after the proposals were finalized earlier today within the Coalition Council. The government's measures are aimed at supporting those fighting in the front lines against the spread of COVID-19 and helping those most affected by the pandemic. The source of expenditures is the national budget, with social measures amounting to BGN 731.5 million and economic ones BGN 431.4 million.    "The goal is to minimize the damage caused by the pandemic in many sectors," said Prime Minister Boyko Borissov.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200730110004/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/438    Part of the announced financial package worth ~$699m is intended as an emergency stimulus for the health system and I've included the difference in H4.

"The Prime Minister announced that from August 1, the staff costs of bodies and administrations responsible for pandemic control and the consequences of COVID-19 will be increased by 30%. For front-line employees, the rate for night work is increased. Additional overtime costs in the amount of BGN 92.0 million are envisaged for the structures of the systems of the Ministry of Health, the Ministry of Labor and Social Policy, the Ministry of Interior, the National Health Insurance Fund, the National Social Security Institute and others.    An additional BGN 24.6 million is allocated to increase from August 1 the standards for the activities delegated by the state for school and children's health care and health offices. The aim is for the payment to reach the certain levels under the Collective Labor Agreement in the Healthcare sector, as well as the standards in the social sphere (homes for the elderly, homes for the disabled, homes for residential services, day care centers for children, accommodation centers from family type, etc.).    In the next three months, all pensioners will receive BGN 50 per month as a supplement to their pensions, thus a total of 2,121,000 pensioners will be supported. The necessary funds for this amount to a total of BGN 318.3 million.    The funds for subsidies of the medical establishments - commercial companies under Ordinance ? 3 for the medical activities outside the scope of the obligatory health insurance, subsidized by the Ministry of Health, are increased by BGN 17.3 million. The funds are provided to achieve the capacity to serve patients with COVID-19 and to reach the levels of wages to the levels of the Collective Labor Agreement.    It is also envisaged to increase the value of health insurance payments for medical and dental care by an average of 10% to a total of BGN 126.3 million. The aim is to increase the costs of medical staff so as to reach the minimum levels of Collective Labor contract.  Another social measure worth BGN 67.0 million, provided by redirecting funds from European programs, is the provision of a net remuneration of BGN 1,000 to the medical specialists involved in the fight against COVID-19 on the first line until the end of 2020.  More than 38,000 people will benefit from the measure worth BGN 8.0 million, representing assistance for the use of basic tourist services for domestic tourism worth BGN 210 for persons who have directly carried out or are carrying out activities related to treatment. , preventing the spread and / or overcoming the effects of COVID - 19."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200730110004/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/438

From 4th August 2020, the Bulgarian government will allow the reopening of outdoor sports events (as stated in an order issued by health minister Kostadin Angelov). Indoor sports matches remain closed to spectators. In the case of outdoor sports matches, no more than 50 per cent of seats may be occupied, there is a limit of 1000 people per sector in a stadium, and physical distancing of 1.5 metres must be maintained.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200820091913/https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/08/04/covid-19-bulgaria-re-opens-outdoor-sports-matches-to-spectators/

As of August 11th 2020, people arriving from the United Arab Emirates can enter Bulgaria without presenting a document showing a negative PCR test result, Bulgaria’s Health Ministry said. Bulgarian citizens, as well as long-term and permanent residents in Bulgaria and the members of their families, who come from countries for which a negative PCR test within the past 72 hours is required, and who do not present such a negative test, are subject to 14 days of quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200820092258/https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/08/11/bulgaria-lifts-pcr-test-requirement-for-arrivals-from-united-arab-emirates/

Schools reopen but are required to meet health and safety standards and should be prepared to switch to distance learning:   "Guided by the belief that learning in the real classroom and directinteraction with teachers and (co) students is the best and irreplaceable alternative, taking into account the views of the various stakeholders and taking into account legal requirements, we decided to attend the launch and conduct of the educational process in full-time form of education for all students and in all schools.  From this decision arise the specific challenges we facefacing the threshold of the 2020-2021 school year in connection with the pandemic:  1. As far as possible to make schools as risk-free as possible, such as we are aware that there is no absolutely safe environment in a pandemic. This suggests each school to implement a set of measures to reduce the risks of transmission of infection, including by creating attitudes of health and social responsibility behavior of children as part of the educational function of education;  2.To react according to the health rules in each case of a patient or with suspected COVID-19;  3. Be prepared to switch to training at the direction of the health authorities electronic environment at a distance (including for individual classes, the whole school or all schools in the municipality, district or state) and in accordance with the decisions of the district crisis headquarters to combat COVID-19"  http://web.archive.org/web/20200923051822/https://www.mon.bg/upload/23842/nasoki-covid19-Uchilishte_09092020.pdf

The changes will be presented to the central bank soon and announced appropriately, if approved”    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207052252/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-bulgaria-banks/bulgarian-banks-consider-extension-of-loan-repayment-delay-idUKL1N2II1VI    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207052344/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No policy change      As of 7 December, the unified information portal remains the official source of information on measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Bulgaria (https://coronavirus.bg). The portal provides statistics, news briefings, video materials, and information about COVID-19 in Bulgaria.     An official chatbot of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria is available, which provides real-time official information and news about COVID-19 through Viber.     The ViruSafe mobile app is available, which gives users the ability to track their symptoms and health status daily. This information gives the Ministry of Health a good overview of the spread of the pandemic. Users can also voluntarily share their location to enable institutions to act accordingly, in case of an emergency.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207053136/https://virusafe.info/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207053225/https://coronavirus.bg/

No policy change    As of 7 December, testing procedures depend on whether you are a first- or second-line contact person, suffer from a chronic illness, fall into the risk category of people over 60, be a medical professional and have symptoms.     Testing for coronavirus is performed at the discretion of the regional health inspectorate, the medical institution where the patient is hospitalized or the relevant medical person in the designated places for examination and diagnosis (based on symptoms) or with a referral (can be issued electronically or on paper) by a general practitioner.    A referral for a PCR test will also be issued to individuals who test positive for a rapid antigen test performed by an authorized medical care provider.    Optional testing can be done in a private laboratory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207053310/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/936    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207053358/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/litse-simptomi

The monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is performed by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspection.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207053433/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse

No policy change    As of 7 December, order RD-01-675 remains in effect.     When serving customers directly, requiring a distance of less than 1.5 meters, the use of a face mask or safety helmet is mandatory.     Customer service without a face mask or safety helmet is allowed when mechanical partitions made of glass or other transparent material are provided, allowing wet cleaning or disinfection.    All persons when in closed public places, including means of public transport, medical and health establishments, pharmacies, opticians, national centers for public health, administrative institutions and other places where they are served or citizens have access to railway and bus stations, airports, metro stations, shops, churches, monasteries, temples, museums, etc., must have a protective face mask for single or multiple use or other means covering the nose and mouth (including a towel, scarf, helmet, etc.).    All persons, when they are in open public places, where there is a crowd of people and impossibility to observe a physical distance of 1.5 m, are obliged to have a protective face mask for single or multiple use or other means of covering nose and mouth (including towel, scarf, helmet, etc.), which are used according to the recommendations in the order.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207051648/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

On 4 December, the National Plan for Vaccination against COVID-19 was adopted. No deliveries yet received so coded as 0    The vaccine for Bulgarian citizens will be completely free and voluntary, according to the Prime Minister.     There are two conditions for immunization - expressed desire and informed consent.    "We are fulfilling our commitment and adopting the National Plan on time. The country is ready and logistically to meet the first delivery of vaccines and, without wasting any time, to start immunization, which will be completely free and voluntary," said Borissov.    The Minister of Health reports that the necessary freezers for storing the vaccines are already available, as well as specialized transport for their delivery in the country. Angelov emphasized that the vaccination plan specifies the phases that determine which groups of the population and in what order will be immunized against the new virus - medical teams, social and pedagogical staff, the elderly over 65 years, patients with chronic diseases."    Parliament has backed the government plan to take part in an EU scheme and get vaccine shots from Pfizer, AstraZeneca and Sanofi.    Vaccines will be administered only with the permission of the European regulator. To ensure that sufficient quantities of COVID-19 vaccines are provided in the country as soon as possible, they will be delivered centrally through a joint EU public procurement mechanism.    The government expects to receive 12-13 million doses at a total cost of about EUR 250 million (USD 304 million).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214235545/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/938    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214235756/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/939    https://web.archive.org/web/20201215015622if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-bulgaria-vaccines/bulgaria-prepares-for-covid-19-vaccines-as-death-rates-spike-idUSKBN28E0Z3

The decision for transitioning to distance learning in an electronic environment was made by the Minister of Education and Science under the conditions and by the order of art. 105, para. 6 and 115a, para. 1, 4 and 5 of the Preschool and School Education Act.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214074705/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

No policy change    As of 14 December, order RD-01-677 remains in effect.     Visits to shopping centers (representing one or more buildings in which shops, restaurants and other commercial sites are located) are suspended. Visits to casinos, gambling halls, and fitness halls are also suspended. Exceptions include grocery stores, hospitals, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet stores, banks, insurers, payment service providers, and telecommunications offices.    If possible, employees are to work remotely. A maximum of 50% of staff are allowed to work in-person. Employers are to establish working hours with variable limits or shifts. Employers are to approve a schedule for the use of regulated holidays, as well as to apply other preventive measures and methods of work, which will provide a better level of protection of workers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214074705/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

No policy change    As of 14 December, order RD-01-677 remains in effect.    The holding of congress-conference events, seminars, competitions, trainings, team building, exhibitions and other public events in attendance is suspended.    All cultural and entertainment events (cinemas, museums, galleries, stage events, concerts, classes in dance, creative and musical arts, etc.) are suspended.    Theaters are an exception, which are allowed to be occupied up to 30% of their total capacity. Observance of a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and protective face masks are required.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214074705/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

No policy change    As of 14 December, order RD-01-677 remains in effect.    It is not allowed to organize and hold gatherings and celebrations of a private nature (weddings, baptisms, funerals, etc.) with the presence of more than 15 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214074705/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

According to order RD-01-675, all persons on public transport (including railways, bus stations, airports, metro stations) must have a protective face mask or other means of covering the nose and mouth (including a towel, scarf, helmet, etc.)     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214074705/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

No policy change    As of 14 December, order RD-01-547 remains in effect.    A temporary ban on entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of all persons has been introduced, regardless of their nationality, at all border crossing points, by air, sea, rail and road.     The ban does not apply to Bulgarian citizens, citizens of Member States of the European Union (EU), the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Schengen countries (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and their family members (including those who are actually living with them); citizens of the Union of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, the Republic of Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, the Kingdom of Thailand, the Republic of Tunisia, the Oriental Republic of Uruguay, the United Arab Emirates, Ukraine, the Republic of Northern Macedonia, the Republic of Serbia and the Republic of Albania Herzegovina, Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova, Israel, The State of Kuwait, the Republic of Belarus and the Republic of Turkey; the persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holding a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D".    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214074705/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

No policy change      As of 14 December, the unified information portal remains the official source of information on measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Bulgaria (https://coronavirus.bg). The portal provides statistics, news briefings, video materials, and information about COVID-19 in Bulgaria.     An official chatbot of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria is available, which provides real-time official information and news about COVID-19 through Viber.     The ViruSafe mobile app is available, which gives users the ability to track their symptoms and health status daily. This information gives the Ministry of Health a good overview of the spread of the pandemic. Users can also voluntarily share their location to enable institutions to act accordingly, in case of an emergency.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207053136/https://virusafe.info/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214231836/https://coronavirus.bg/

No policy change    As of 14 December, testing procedures depend on whether the individual is a first- or second-line contact person, suffers from a chronic illness, falls into the risk category of people over 60, is a medical professional, and has symptoms.     Testing for coronavirus is performed at the discretion of the regional health inspectorate, the medical institution where the patient is hospitalized or the relevant medical person in the designated places for examination and diagnosis (based on symptoms) or with a referral (can be issued electronically or on paper) by a general practitioner.    A referral for a PCR test will also be issued to individuals who test positive for a rapid antigen test performed by an authorized medical care provider.    Optional testing can be done in a private laboratory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214232532/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/936    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214083718/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/litse-simptomi

No policy change    As of 14 December, all close contacts in a confirmed case of COVID-19, at the discretion of an epidemiologist from the regional health inspectorate, are placed under quarantine at home or elsewhere for accommodation and medical supervision for 10-day period, as of the last contact with the sick person.    The monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is performed by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspection.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214084030/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse

No policy change    As of 14 December, order RD-01-675 remains in effect.     When serving customers directly, requiring a distance of less than 1.5 meters, the use of a face mask or safety helmet is mandatory.     Customer service without a face mask or safety helmet is allowed when mechanical partitions made of glass or other transparent material are provided, allowing wet cleaning or disinfection.    All persons when in closed public places, including means of public transport, medical and health establishments, pharmacies, opticians, national centers for public health, administrative institutions and other places where they are served or citizens have access to railway and bus stations, airports, metro stations, shops, churches, monasteries, temples, museums, etc., must have a protective face mask for single or multiple use or other means covering the nose and mouth (including a towel, scarf, helmet, etc.).    All persons, when they are in open public places, where there is a crowd of people and impossibility to observe a physical distance of 1.5 m, are obliged to have a protective face mask for single or multiple use or other means of covering nose and mouth (including towel, scarf, helmet, etc.), which are used according to the recommendations in the order.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214074705/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

No policy change     As of 9 December, over BGN 585 million has been transferred so far to the companies and enterprises that have applied under the measure 60/40 for maintaining the employment of their employees.     The jobs saved are about 250,000, and all workers receive their full wages and insurances. The state compensations amount to 60% of the due salaries and insurances, and the employers are obliged to insure the remaining 40%.     Employers whose activities have been suspended due to the anti-epidemic measures imposed can apply to the employment offices under the Save Me project. Their employees are entitled to receive BGN 24 per day for the period in which they were on unpaid leave. For employees of 4 hours the compensation is BGN 12 per day. Compensation will be paid for a maximum of 60 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214080028/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/960    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214080219/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/socialni

On 9 December, BGN 22,280,000 (USD 13,757,559) was allocated by the government to BUL BIO for investment projects developed by the company. The projects include the construction of a new, additional production line for BCG vaccine, the renovation of a laboratory for the production of human blood products, the resumption of the production of antitoxic sera from horse plasma.    "The funds will go to these areas in BUL BIO, so that Bulgarians know that we have invested in the creation of vaccines. Bulgaria produces not only vaccines, but also antitoxic serums and everything else for a huge number of countries around the world," said the Prime Minister during the government meeting.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214234020/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/957

On 11 December, the Governing Council of the Bulgarian National Bank approved the extension of the "Procedure for deferral and settlement of due liabilities to banks and their subsidiaries - financial institutions".      This is the second extension of this policy. Originally introduced in April, it allowed for people and companies to stop servicing their bank loans for up to six months.    Borrowers will now be able to negotiate with lenders until 31 March 2021 to delay payments of both interest and the principal for nine months. Those who have already had six months of loan repayment holidays can negotiate three additional months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214230757/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/972    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214230618/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-bulgaria-banks/bulgarian-banks-extend-loan-repayment-moratorium-idUSL1N2IR173    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213231506/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

On 22 December, order RD-01-718 went into effect.    Attended classes (including internships, external classes, exams, dual training system, etc.) in schools and personal development support centers are suspended.    The present learning process in the higher schools is suspended, except for the holding of state exams.    Attended group classes in language centers, educational centers and other training centers and schools organized by legal entities and individuals are suspended.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

On 22 December, order RD-01-718 went into effect. Order RD-01-675 also remains in effect.    Employers and recruitment bodies are to organize the work process of employees in remote form (teleworking / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of a maximum of 50% of staff.    The work process of the collective management bodies and the employees should be carried out, if possible, in remote form (home work / remote work) or to establish working hours with variable limits or work in shifts. Employers to approve a schedule for the use of regulated holidays, where applicable, as well as to apply other preventive measures and methods of work, depending on the specifics of the respective work activity, which will provide a better level of protection of workers.    Visits to shopping centers (representing one or more buildings in which shops, restaurants and other commercial sites are located) are suspended, except for grocery stores, hospitals, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet stores, banks, insurers, payment service providers, offices of telecommunications operators and other providers of communications and utility services and dry cleaning services therein. On 22 December, order RD-01-718 went into effect.    The holding of sports events with training and competitive character in the collective sports for persons under 18 years of age is suspended. An exception is allowed only for registered athletes to sports federations. Sports competitions for all age groups are held without an audience.    All cultural and entertainment events (cinemas, museums, galleries, stage events, concerts, classes in dance, creative and musical arts, etc.) are suspended. An exception is allowed with regard to the theaters, when the seats are occupied up to 30% of their total capacity, observance of a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and mandatory placement of protective face masks.    The holding of congress-conference events, seminars, competitions, trainings, team building, exhibitions and other public events in attendance is suspended. The ban does not apply to competitions held in accordance with the Labor Code, the Civil Servant Act, the Academic Staff Development Act in the Republic of Bulgaria and other special laws.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

On 22 December, the government allocated nearly BGN 184 million (USD 48,996,143) for the readiness of hospitals to provide medical care in the declared epidemic, for the provision of vaccines and additional quantities of the drug remdesivir, as well as for the construction of a new system for receiving emergency calls to improve the service for the European number 112 in the territory of Bulgaria.    Of the BGN 184 million:  - 105 million was allocated for the purchase of vaccines (coded as H5).  - 45 million was allocated to medical establishments for hospital care as a subsidy for maintaining their readiness for rendering medical aid in the declared emergency epidemic situation.  - 19,440,000 was allocated for the purchase of remdesivir used in the treatment of COVID-19.   - 14.3 million was allocated for a new emergency call system.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210102232250/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1031

On 23 December, the 60/40 measure in support of business and workers was extended until September 2021    "Eligible applicants for the measure are employers from the sectors of passenger and urban transport, passenger land transport, hotels, restaurants. On the night of 24 December, equipped with all necessary protective equipment - masks, gloves and disinfectants - Santa Claus and his reindeer team travels from Lapland and is expected to arrive in Bulgaria, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.    According to official sources, as a representative of one of the risk groups, the White-bearded old man has already been vaccinated and is ready to make all children and adults happy with gifts on Christmas Eve. Although some of the restrictions imposed on entry and mandatory quarantine do not apply to him, he and the deer are still obliged to wear protective masks where this has been introduced as a measure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103051139/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1047

A:    On 27 December, the immunization campaign against COVID-19 in Bulgaria began.    The Minister of Health was the first Bulgarian to be vaccinated against coronavirus infection.     163 medical staff from 12 hospitals in Sofia also received the vaccine. Another 440 medics will be immunized in the coming days.    Apart from Sofia, the immunization campaign against COVID-19 in the country started simultaneously in Plovdiv and Burgas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103050522/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1058

As of 3 January, orders RD-01-719 and RD-01-725 remain in effect.    A temporary ban has been introduced for the entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of all persons, regardless of their citizenship, through all border crossings, by air, sea, rail and road transport.     The ban does not apply to Bulgarian citizens, citizens of Member States of the European Union (EU), Schengen Parties (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and their family members (including persons in actual residence with them); citizens of the Union of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, the Republic of Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, the Kingdom of Thailand, the Republic of Tunisia, the Oriental Republic of Uruguay, the United Arab Emirates, Ukraine, the Republic of Northern Macedonia, the Republic of Serbia and the Republic of Albania Herzegovina, Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova, Israel, the State of Kuwait, the Republic of Belarus and the Republic of Turkey; the persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holders of a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons who have a residence permit in a Member State of the European Union or in a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and members of their families.     A temporary ban has been introduced for entering the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria through all border crossings, by air, sea, rail and road transport of all persons arriving with a starting point of departure from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.    The prohibition does not apply to Bulgarian citizens and persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria, to members of their families, as well as to other groups of persons specified in the order.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Attended classes (including internships, internships, outsourced classes, exams, dual system of training, etc.) in schools and personal development support centers are suspended. A:    The immunization of the second and third phases of the National Vaccination Plan against COVID-19 will be carried out in parallel. The members of the Central Election Commission, the district and section commissions, with which the third phase of the plan has started, will be offered the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine. This ensures that the immunization is completed with two doses of the vaccine, so that those involved in the election can be maximally protected from the virus by election day. The overlap of the phases allows Bulgarian journalists, cameramen and photojournalists to be immunized in the third phase of the Plan.     The third phase will continue with employees of Kozloduy Nuclear Power Plant, water supply and sewage companies employed in the transport and communications sectors, and police officers working on the first line.    Vaccination of vulnerable groups remains a top priority for the Ministry of Health. Therefore, the end of the third phase of the National Vaccination Plan will be covered by the beginning of the fourth. In this phase, those covered by immunization will be "Elderly people over 65 years of age and those with concomitant chronic diseases, due to the more severe course of the disease and the higher risk of complications and death, including immunocompromised or persons with secondary immune deficiencies."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209065902/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1292

As of 1 February, visits to hospital facilities are prohibited, except for visits to patients in the terminal stage.     Only people age 65 or older are allowed to shop in grocery stores between 8.30am and 10.30am.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210209041048/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

A:    More than 5,000 teachers and support staff in Sofia have expressed a desire to be immunized against COVID-19. This is a little over 20% of the pedagogical and non-pedagogical staff in the kindergartens and schools in the municipality of Sofia. Vaccination began on February 1, and more than 160 people were immunized in just one day.     The Sofia Regional Health Inspectorate has so far received about 30,000 doses of Pfizer / BioNTech and Moderna vaccines, informed the director of SRHI, Dr. Dancho Penchev. He explained that the first phase of the National Vaccination Plan is coming to an end in the capital, which includes the medical staff of outpatient and inpatient care facilities, medical specialists in health care, dentists, pharmacists, assistant pharmacists and other support staff.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209070608/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1263

On 3 February, nearly BGN 2.9 billion was allocated to support agricultural producers in 2021. The funds are planned to finance direct area payments, market measures, the Rural Development Program (RDP 2014-2020) and the Maritime Affairs Program and fisheries 2014-2020.    Of these, BGN 2.636 billion are from the EU budget and BGN 247 million (USD 151,851,703.22) are from the national budget.    This was approved by the Council of Ministers, which adopted the annual estimates of the account for the European Union funds of the State Fund "Agriculture" for 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210211202059/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1269

In connection with false information published on Internet sites that the NHIF suspends payments for first-line work in the health system, the Ministry of Health states categorically that the state has provided funds for payments for first-line work in the amount of BGN 1,000 for all medical institutions. for hospital care and general practitioners.    Payments for the financing of the additional remuneration of medical and non-medical staff directly engaged in monitoring, diagnosis and treatment of patients with proven coronavirus in hospitals and complex oncology centers, including for activities in January this year, are maintained in 2021    The amount of these payments remains unchanged and amounts to BGN 1,000 net. The aim is to maintain the motivation of staff facing the challenges of fighting the pandemic. The funds in 2021 will be provided from the state budget, through a transfer to the National Health Insurance Fund, and not, as before, through European funding.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209071904/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1282

The aid must be used as a matter of priority to reimburse passengers whose packages have been canceled due to COVID-19 for the same period. All delivered quantities of AstraZeneca vaccine to be used for the first dose, decided today at its regular meeting the Council of the National Vaccination Headquarters. In this way, larger groups of the population will be covered and the immunization process will be accelerated.    The staff will recommend that medical professionals administer the second dose of the vaccine ten weeks after the first, according to the possibilities provided by the summary of product characteristics.    The members of the vaccination headquarters expressed the opinion that the Oxford vaccine can be used for vaccination of all Bulgarian citizens aged 18 and over.    It became clear at the meeting that the delivery of the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine was postponed due to bad weather conditions, and is expected to arrive in Bulgaria in the middle of the week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209065902/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1292

As of 9 February, the temporary ban for the entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of remains in effect.    The ban does not apply to Bulgarian citizens, citizens of Member States of the European Union (EU), Schengen Parties (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and their family members (including persons in actual residence with them); citizens of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the Union of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, the Republic of Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, the Kingdom of Thailand, the Republic of Tunisia, the Oriental Republic of Uruguay, the United Arab Emirates, Ukraine, the Republic of Northern Macedonia The Republic of Albania, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova, Israel, the State of Kuwait, the Republic of Belarus and the Republic of Turkey; persons with permanent status, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holding a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons holding a residence permit in a Member State of the European Union or a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the City State Vatican) and members of their families.    All persons who are allowed to enter the country are admitted to the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria upon submission of a document showing a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test conducted up to 72 hours before entry to prove COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209041048/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 9 February, the loan repayment moratorium remains in effect.    Borrowers are able to negotiate with lenders until 31 March 2021 to delay payments of both interest and the principal for nine months. Those who have already had six months of loan repayment holidays can negotiate three additional months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209054115/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102210418/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/972

As of 9 February, the unified information portal remains the official source of information on measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Bulgaria (https://coronavirus.bg). The portal provides statistics, news, press briefings, video materials, information about vaccines, and answers to frequently asked questions.     An official chatbot of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria is available, which provides real-time official information and news about COVID-19 through Viber.     The ViruSafe mobile app is available, which gives users the ability to track their symptoms and health status daily. This information gives the Ministry of Health a good overview of the spread of the pandemic. Users can also voluntarily share their location to enable institutions to act accordingly, in case of an emergency.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209054901/https://virusafe.info/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206050526/https://coronavirus.bg/

As of 9 February, testing procedures depend on whether the individual is a first- or second-line contact person, suffers from a chronic illness, falls into the risk category of people over 60, is a medical professional, and has symptoms.     Testing for coronavirus is performed at the discretion of the regional health inspectorate, the medical institution where the patient is hospitalized or the relevant medical person in the designated places for examination and diagnosis (based on symptoms) or with a referral from a general practitioner.    Optional testing can be done in a private laboratory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209055248/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/litse-simptomi

As of 9 February, all close contacts in a confirmed case of COVID-19, at the discretion of an epidemiologist from the regional health inspectorate, are placed under quarantine at home or elsewhere for accommodation and medical supervision for 10-day period, as of the last contact with the sick person. The monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is performed by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspection.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209055620/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse

As of 9 February, all persons when in closed public places, including means of public transport, medical and health establishments, pharmacies, opticians, national centers for public health, administrative institutions, railway and bus stations, airports, metro stations, shops, churches, monasteries, temples, and museums are required to have a protective face mask for single or multiple use, which is used according to the recommendations in the order.     All persons, when they are in open public places, where there is a crowd of people and the impossibility to observe a physical distance of 1.5 m, are required to have a protective face mask for single or multiple use, which is used according to the recommendations in the order.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210209041048/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

A:    Vaccines for all those wishing to participate in the election process are provided, Angelov was adamant. The Ministry of Health has sent a letter to the CEC requesting a list of names and contact details of the people to be immunized. The aim is to create an organization that ensures the safe conduct of parliamentary elections.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210211230615/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1297

On 10 March, The Council of Ministers approved additional expenditures from the budget of the Ministry of Health for 2021 in the amount of BGN 7 million (USD 4,258,847) to provide personal protective equipment, medical devices, medicines and disinfectant for the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315012300/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1474

On 12 March, executive director Bogdan Kirilov issued an order which temporarily suspended immunizations with the AstraZeneca vaccine.     The order is in connection with the information received in the period 8-12 March about the occurrence of unacceptable side effects with proper use of the vaccine and the ongoing inspection of the European Medicines Agency.    AstraZeneca vaccines will remain blocked until circumstances are established and recommendations are received from the EMA's Pharmacovigilance Committee.      Also on 12 March, registration on the electronic COVID-19 vaccination portal was suspended. This was due to the temporary suspension of the AstraZeneca vaccine.     Users registered in the portal will automatically receive a new immunization hour, after analyzing the number of people registered for vaccination and the availability of the other two vaccines against COVID-19 approved in our country.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210315172006/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1508    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315172518/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1511

On 13 March, temporary, stricter anti-epidemic measures were introduced in Dobrich district.     The order stipulates that the organization and holding of gatherings and celebrations of a private nature (weddings, baptisms, funerals) are limited to 10 people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210315013446/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1512

As of 14 March, attended classes (including internships, outsourced classes, exams, dual system of education) in schools and personal development support centers are suspended.     Current exceptions include:  Classes for 1st through 4th grades and individual attendance visits to the centers for support of personal development.    Classes for 6th, 9th, and 12th grades, between 3 March and 17 March.     Classes for all students who study in special schools for students with sensory disabilities.    Kindergartens and nurseries.     Exams and practical trainings.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210314183013/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 14 March, discos, bars, and clubs are closed.     Fitness centers and group gyms are allowed with a 50% capacity limit. A distance of at least 2 meters between visitors must be maintained.    Restaurants are allowed with a 50% capacity limit and not more than 6 people per table. Staff are required to wear protective masks and hours are limited to between 06:00 and 23:00.    Gaming halls and casinos are allowed with a 50% capacity limit. Staff and visitors are required to wear protective masks and hours are limited to between 06:00 and 23:00.    Visits to shopping centers, including malls, are allowed. Minors may only visit them if they are accompanied by their parent, guardian, or another adult.    Markets and bazaars must be organized for one-way movement of visitors and must provide a distance of at least 1.5m between visitors. Workers and visitors are required to wear a face mask.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314183013/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 14 March, all cultural and entertainment events (cinemas, museums, galleries, stage events, concerts, classes in dance, creative and musical arts) are suspended.    Current exceptions include:   Theaters, museums, and galleries at a maximum of 30% capacity. Observance of a physical distance of at least 1.5m and protective face masks are mandatory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314183013/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 14 March, public transport remains open with mask wearing requirements.    All persons must cover their mouth and nose with a mask or covering on all public transportation including while in railway, bus and metro stations, and airports.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314183013/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314202453/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of 14 March, no stay-at-home measures are in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314183013/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314202453/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
As of 14 March, there are no restrictions on internal movement between regions of Bulgaria.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210314202453/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of 14 March, the ban on entry into the Republic of Bulgaria remains in effect, with certain exceptions.    Current exceptions include:  Bulgarian citizens, citizens of Member States of the European Union (EU), Schengen Parties (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and their family members (including persons in actual residence with them); citizens of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the Union of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, the Republic of Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, the Kingdom of Thailand, the Republic of Tunisia, the Oriental Republic of Uruguay, the United Arab Emirates, Ukraine, the Republic of Northern Macedonia The Republic of Albania, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova, Israel, the State of Kuwait, the Republic of Belarus and the Republic of Turkey; persons with permanent status, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holding a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons holding a residence permit in a Member State of the European Union or in a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the City State Vatican) and members of their families.    All persons who are allowed to enter the country are admitted to the Republic of Bulgaria upon submission of a document showing a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test conducted up to 72 hours before entry.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210314183013/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 14 March, the acceptance of applications for payment of funds under measure 60/40 continues. The application for the measure will continue under the terms of the adopted amendments to Decree 151 of the Council of Ministers of 2020, providing for extension of the deadline for payment of funds until March 31, 2021.     The 60/40 wage subsidy program finances 60% of wages.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210209053103/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ikonomicheski

As of 14 March, the loan repayment moratorium remains in effect.    Borrowers are able to negotiate with lenders until 31 March 2021 to delay payments of both interest and the principal for nine months. Those who have already had six months of loan repayment holidays can negotiate three additional months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314233557/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/972

As of 14 March, the unified information portal remains the official source of information on measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Bulgaria (https://coronavirus.bg). The portal provides statistics, news, press briefings, video materials, information about vaccines, and answers to frequently asked questions.     An official chatbot of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria is available, which provides real-time official information and news about COVID-19 through Viber.     The ViruSafe mobile app is available, which gives users the ability to track their symptoms and health status daily. This information gives the Ministry of Health a good overview of the spread of the pandemic. Users can also voluntarily share their location to enable institutions to act accordingly, in case of an emergency.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210314185439/https://coronavirus.bg/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209054901/https://virusafe.info/

As of 14 March, testing procedures depend on whether the individual is a first- or second-line contact person, suffers from a chronic illness, falls into the risk category of people over 60, is a medical professional, and has symptoms.     Testing for coronavirus is performed at the discretion of the regional health inspectorate, the medical institution where the patient is hospitalized or the relevant medical person in the designated places for examination and diagnosis (based on symptoms) or with a referral from a general practitioner.    Optional testing can be done in a private laboratory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314223322/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/litse-simptomi

As of 14 March, all close contacts in a confirmed case of COVID-19, at the discretion of an epidemiologist from the regional health inspectorate, are placed under quarantine at home or elsewhere for accommodation and medical supervision for 10-day period, as of the last contact with the sick person.    The monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is performed by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspection.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314223914/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse

As of 14 March, all persons when in closed public places, including means of public transport, medical and health establishments, pharmacies, opticians, national centers for public health, administrative institutions, railway and bus stations, airports, metro stations, shops, churches, monasteries, temples, and museums are required to wear a protective face mask.    All persons, when they are in open public places, where there is a crowd of people and the impossibility to observe a physical distance of 1.5m, are required to wear a protective face mask.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314183013/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

RD-01-168 of 15.03.2021, attended classes (including internships, external classes, exams, dual system of education) in schools and personal development support centers are suspended. On 26 March, an extraordinary government meeting approved an additional BGN 96 million (USD 57,914,608) from the budget of the Ministry of Health.    Of the total amount, BGN 46 million is earmarked for the purchase of Remdesivir, so that the treatment of patients with coronavirus infection in hospitals can be provided with this drug until September, inclusive.    The remaining BGN 50 million are a transfer to the budget of the National Health Insurance Fund. The funds provide additional remuneration of BGN 1,000 for the month of April for those working on the first line in the fight against COVID-19, directly engaged in the treatment of patients with coronavirus infection, as well as for the payment of vaccines against COVID-19.     Unclear what proportion is allocated for vaccines, so this was not coded separately under H5.     https://archive.vn/lRm1D

As of June 23, wearing a face mask or other protective means in indoor public places becomes compulsory again. The rule doesn’t apply only for the costumers in restaurants and bars. Athletes and other people practicing sports indoors are excluded from this obligation, but the audience, trainers and other staff members must wear protective masks.  • The audience at sports events could be up to 50% of the standard capacity of the venue, assuring 1.5 meters distance between each individual. According to IMF: Expenditures for business support: (i) 60/40 wage subsidy scheme (BGN 1136 mn); (ii) support for artists, who have been hit by the lockdown (BGN 5 mn); (iii) tourism support (BGN 62 mn) and (iv) agricultural producers support (BGN 85 mn).  This information is confirmed on EU website: on 30 March 2021, the Commission approved the modification of a scheme providing wage support to employers and the self-employed in sectors most affected by the coronavirus outbreak. Under the state aid Temporary Framework, the scheme, first approved in July 2020 and previously extended in December 2020, was granted a second extension until end-2021, a budgetary increase from approximately €20.5 million to around €76.7 million, and amendments extending the scope of the eligible beneficiaries. According to the government website the following temporary anti-epidemic measures are in place regarding the entry of persons arriving from other countries on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria, as of September 1, 2021 to November 30, 2021, according to an assessment of the spread of COVID-19 in the respective country by criteria and placing the countries in color zones as follows: (zones are determined according to the COVID incidence of the country)  - Green zone  - allowed on the territory of the country upon presentation of a valid EU digital COVID certificate for vaccination, disease or testing or a similar document containing the same data as the EU digital COVID certificate  - Orange zone  - allowed on the territory of the country only upon presentation of a valid EU digital COVID certificate for vaccination, disease or testing or a similar document containing the same data as the EU digital COVID certificate  - Red zone  - on the territory of the country are allowed only persons who are: --> long list of different possibilities    The persons returning from a red zone, which do not present a valid EU digital COVID certificate for vaccination or for illness or similar document, may be admitted to the territory of the country only after presentation of a negative result from a test conducted up to 72 hours before entering the country by the method of polymerase chain reaction for COVID-19, certified by a valid EU digital COVID certificate for testing or a similar document containing the same data as the EU digital COVID certificate for testing and quarantine for a period of 10 days at home or elsewhere for accommodation in which the person has indicated that he will reside, with a prescription issued by the director of the respective regional health inspectorate or a deputy director authorized by him.    Ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.04-215415/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Testing procedures depend on whether the persons are a first- or second-line contact person, suffer from a chronic illness, fall into the risk category of people over the age of 60, be a medical professional, or have symptoms. The monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is performed by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspection.  Ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.05-084421/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse
No new announcement was made between September 1 and October 4 about budget for vaccination.   Ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.05-090114/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news?p=20%23

According to the US embassy in Bukgaria: All persons must wear a mask that covers their mouth and nose in all indoor public spaces (including hospitals, pharmacies, administrative institutions, shops, malls, churches, museums, and all public transportation including railway, bus and metro stations, and airports, etc.) as well as in open public spaces where there is a crowd of people and impossibility to observe a physical distance of 1.5 m. Scarves or substitute face coverings are no longer allowed in place of a mask.  Ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.04-222844/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Since june 2021, in connection with a number of inquiries received, the Ministry of Health informed that as of June 3 this year (2021), children over 12 years of age can be vaccinated against COVID-19 with the vaccine of the manufacturer Pfizer / BioNTech.   Ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.05-092315/https://www.mh.government.bg/bg/novini/aktualno/vaksinirane-na-deca-sreshu-covid-19/
No new measures were announced for elderly people.   Ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.04-215415/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Temporary anti-epidemic measures from September 4 are introduced in Sliven region by decision of the Regional Crisis Staff with stop of holding of all public events and events related to the gathering of people indoors and outdoors.  Ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.05-180637/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/2387

According to the government covid website, new anti-epidemic measures will be applied starting from september 7 with conducting face-to-face group classes in language centers, educational centers and other training centers and schools is allowed subject to a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and not more than 10 people in a room, wearing protective face masks, hand hygiene, regular airing every hour and disinfection.  This is not a recommendation of closing schools but there will be a significant difference than ususal with no more than 10 persons/classroom.   Ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.04-215415/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

according to governement website:   - The  holding of all mass events, such as music and other festivals, fairs, folklore initiatives and others of such nature, where the attendees are not organized with certain seats and the entrance (participation) is unlimited, is suspended.  - The holding of sports competitions with a professional character indoors is allowed without an audience.    - The holding of sports competitions of a professional nature in the open air is allowed with an audience when occupying not more than 30% of the capacity, using only seats when occupying every third seat, observing a physical distance of at least 1.5 m, and wearing protective face masks by visitors.    ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.04-215415/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

According to government website starting from september  7: The holding of gatherings of a private nature (baptisms, weddings, etc.) is allowed with the participation of not more than 30 persons indoors and 60 persons outdoors.
